TEXT: The applicant , PERSON , is a NORP national , who was born in DATE and lives in GPE , GPE . He is represented before the ORG by PERSON PERSON , a lawyer practising in GPE .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the applicant , may be summarised as follows .
In DATE , criminal investigations were initiated against the applicant on the suspicion of his participation in planning several transactions of illegal sales of weapons to GPE .

On DATE , ORG convicted the applicant of several counts of offences under LAW ( PERSON ) . It found that he had counselled and participated in planning the illegal sales of weapons to GPE . The applicant was sentenced to CARDINAL months’ imprisonment on probation .

On DATE , ORG , upon the applicant ’s appeal , amended the ORG decision to the effect that he was found guilty of CARDINAL offence under LAW . It imposed a fine amounting to CARDINAL DATE rates of CARDINAL DEM ( approximately CARDINAL Euro ) .

On DATE , following the applicant ’s appeal on points of law , ORG repealed this decision and referred the case back to a different chamber of ORG . It found that the procedural delays caused by judicial organs had not been taken into account by the lower court .

On DATE , ORG confirmed its decision of DATE . It briefly mentioned the delays in proceedings , but found that , bearing in mind the gravity of the offence , CARDINAL DATE rates was the lowest possible sentence .

On DATE , ORG , following the applicant ’s second appeal on points of law , also quashed the decision of DATE and referred the case back to yet another chamber of ORG . It found that the judicial organs had unnecessarily prolonged proceedings for DATE and that this constituted a violation of LAW ) and of LAW . However , it found that , contrary to the applicant ’s submissions , this did not constitute a procedural impediment that would warrant for proceedings to be discontinued . Finally , ORG noted that in its decisions , ORG had failed to show if and to what extent the excessive length of proceedings had an effect on the sentence .
On DATE , ORG amended the decisions of DATE and DATE while changing the sentence to the effect that the fine was reduced to CARDINAL DATE rates of CARDINAL ORG .

It found that the following delays had been unnecessary and were attributable to the judicial organs : although ORG had been in possession of most of the relevant information by DATE , the indictment was not submitted before DATE , which amounted to a delay of DATE and DATE . ORG decision of CARDINAL DATE , having been finalised for service on DATE , was not served upon the applicant before DATE , i. e. DATE . The proceedings were not furthered between DATE and DATE , when the case was transferred to ORG . In appeal proceedings before ORG , ORG took DATE and DATE ( DATE ) to submit its memorial to ORG . These delays amounted to DATE in total .

ORG found that the delays and the excessive length of proceedings were in breach of LAW CARDINAL of the Convention . Having regard to all circumstances , ORG concluded that the procedural delays did not require that the proceedings be discontinued . Weighing all personal mitigating and aggravating factors , ORG found that , without taking account of the procedural delays , it would have imposed a fine of CARDINAL DATE rates of CARDINAL ORG . It reduced the fine to CARDINAL DATE rates , on account of the above - mentioned delays in the past , and , in a second step , further reduced the fine to CARDINAL DATE rates , considering the further delays caused by the appeal proceedings .
On DATE , ORG rejected the applicant ’s appeal .

On DATE , ORG refused to entertain the applicant ’s constitutional complaint . ORG found , in particular , that ORG had given a detailed account of the delays attributable to the judiciary and had taken these delays into account when reducing the fine by CARDINAL DATE rates . The reduced fine did not reach the statutory limits for inclusion in a certificate of good conduct ( PERSON ) and would be removed from the applicant ’s criminal record after the minimum statutory period . ORG had therefore sufficiently reduced the sentence on account of the procedural delays .
